story.text: (Adds quote, flex-fuel vehicle sales)SAO PAULO, Brazil Jan 2 (Reuters) - New motor vehicle sales in Brazil rose 12.1 percent in December to a record 204,800 units, helped by a stable economy and cheaper credit, the automakers group Anfavea said on Tuesday. Sales for the year rose 12.4 percent from 2005 to nearly 1.93 million units, a couple thousand units short of the record number of vehicles sold in 1997. "We didn't beat the record but we returned to a similar sales level as in 1997," Rogelio Golfarb, Anfavea's president, said at a news conference. "Lower interest rates were the main stimulus." Anfavea said about 2.63 million units were produced in 2006, a climb of 4 percent. It said exports were about $12.1 billion. The group expects production to rise about 3.8 percent in 2007 and exports to remain stable. Sales of flex-fuel vehicles, running on any mixture of sugar cane-based ethanol, represented 82 percent of total new light vehicle sales in December, up from 81.4 percent in November. A total of 2.6 million flex-fuel vehicles have been sold since they were launched on the market at the start of 2003, Golfarb said.
story.title: update 1 - brazil auto vehicle sales rise to record in dec
